title: Journalists receive training on Open Budget Survey
text:
9 September 2015 17:00 CET Journalists receive training on Open Budget Survey By GNA 
Accra, Sept. 9, GNA - About 25 selected journalists have benefitted from the Open Budget Survey (OBS) training workshop in Accra. 
The workshop, which was funded by the International Budget Partnership (IBP), was a precursor to the national launch of the OBS results for 2015 which would be announced this month. 
It aimed mainly at deepening the understanding of the journalists on what the OBS and Tracker was, how countries were assessed and how to independently monitor the publication of eight key budget documents. 
The training also provided journalists the opportunity to ask critical questions regarding progress of Ghana's budget formulation and implementation in order to equip themselves to be able to educate and influence the broader society to demand accountability and equity in the utilization of the budget. 
Ms Harriet Nuamah-Agyemang, a Programme Officer at SEND Ghana, explained that the organisation believed that budget tracking and monitoring was a very important tool that could be used to measure how transparent and accountable Ghana's budget is. 
She said all the eight key budget documents that could be tracked must be provided by the Finance Ministry and should be easily accessible to all citizens. 
'The documents should also be devoid of technicalities in order for everybody to understand,' she added. 
She entreated participants to create awareness of OBS among the citizenry. 
'We believe that the media is able to reach our citizenry within a short time at a relatively moderate cost and, therefore, can help stimulate and influence public debate on how best to ensure that the monies allocated by government to the various ministries are used judiciously,' she said. 
The IBP conducts a survey to track government's performance in order to find out whether government was doing well with respect to the OBS. 
The eight documents accessed include: pre-Budget Statement, executive Budget Proposal, citizens' Budget, in-Year Reports, audit Report, year End Report and mid-Year Report. 
GNA
